@AmazonHelp Done, but if I get a useless response again, I'm just going to stop notifying you all about this.  Your inability to deliver package to the correct location is really not my problem.

@AmazonHelp This is obviously not true, since it was delivered to the wrong person at the wrong address on the wrong street, as I noted in my message to them: "Recipient was supposed to be McDavid Maddox at 212 N Duke St. Apt 212, was instead delivered to 610 W Main St. Apt 212."

@AmazonHelp I tried that yesterday, the response I got was "The location that the package has been delivered to is the location suggest by the purchaser. The customer has been notified of the package left at that location." 1/2

@AmazonHelp two days in a row!  This package was intended for Robert Vogel 212 N Duke St Apt 229, instead delivered to me 610 W Main St apt 212. It would be funny, except... package left in mailroom, again. https://t.co/xhBpxA5Iov
@AmazonHelp That picture is really all the details I have.  It got delivered outside my door between 5:00 and 8:00 PM.
@AmazonHelp another misdelivered package.  Should have gone to 212 Duke St. Apt 212, instead went to 610 W Main St. Apt 212.  Put in the mail room if anyone is looking for it. https://t.co/Q3rCQrC7Mx
@AmazonHelp It wasn’t my order in this case, but Amazon is the only carrier that delivers to the door, other carriers use the package room/ package concierge system.

@amazon prime continues to deliver packages to the wrong building in my apartment complex. Today I got someone else’s package from another building. Clearly they need to fix the local delivery problem or go back to using UPS, FedEx, and USPS.

3 ways to grow a B2B software business:

1. You do sales.
2. Your customers do sales.
3. You help your customers to do sales.

If 2 happens at all 3 might be the most profitable way to invest your time.

Another huge influence on me:

I estimate >80% of my income over the last decade has been funded by self-service @stripe sales.

At Stripe entire teams *developers included* are encouraged to interview customers directly.

They don't make great products by accident.
